title: What was the weakest Led Zeppelin album? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’d say Coda. They put it out therefore it counts. In Through the Out Door more about John Paul Jones keyboards and contributions than Pages guitar dominance. From what I’ve read Jones was right on the cutting edge of what was the explosion of synths. You don’t hear him getting credit like Stevie Wonder or whatever but I’ve read that he was right up there Stevie Wonder and Herbie Hancock with networking keyboards and pushing the boundaries of technology in a world where MIDI had not been invented. Led Zeppelin was not all about Page and ITTOD was Jones album to shine. I don’t think it’s weak as much as it’s just not as guitar laden as prior albums. And the keys are providing that density. Presence has one of my all time favorite Page songs on it. And there’s a couple of shining moments. By all accounts the band was really struggling during recording. Plants injury. Tax exile. The death of Plants son. And they also simply ran out of studio time. I feel it was put out not quite done. None of the songs are horrible. It was just a dark time for the band and it showed. Its hard to look at Achilles and say Page was off when even he’s said that’s probably one of his best solos. Add in 11 to seven distinct guitar parts and the tempo and it’s really hard to say he was off his game. Various albums have been remastered. It would be interesting to hand over the raw tracks of Presence to someone like Eddie Kramer and see what a entirely new mix might do. And that’s a part of Presences problem. The actual mix is relatively flat and lifeless. Nothing is out front and nothing reaches out to grab you. Compare the explosive mix of something like The Song Remains the Same off of Houses of The Holy and that energy is just not there. That said. I don’t think I’ve pulled Coda out for decades.

In my estimation it is ‘In Through The Out Door’, though votes for ‘Presence’ or ‘Coda’ or are just as valid. Don’t get me wrong, it’s a good LP by most band’s standards, but it doesn’t really sound like a Zep record, due to Page’s negligible contributions. The band had really run out of steam due to many factors but at the time of the recording of ‘out door’ Page’s addiction and Bonham’s alcoholism were out of control. So much so that Plant and Jones reportedly would work by day and page and Bonham would arrive at night, sometimes, to add their efforts to what the singer and bassist had done. Although Page is given perfunctory co-songwriting credits on half the tunes, for his guitar parts I assume, in truth all the songs belonged to the morning crew, with a much heavier than usual JPJ influence. Some of Plant’s attempts to broaden and try to remain relevant in a changing musical landscape (similar to Jagger’s sometimes ill-advised attempts with the Stones) on the album were unwarranted. At least the thrown-together and uneven ‘Coda’, or the mediocre and bland “Presence’ still sounded like Zeppelin, while “Out Door” sounds like a Plant/Jones Band album with Page as a guest guitarist with some god-awful drumming/percussion. Like I said though, still a good record but, in my view LZ’s worst.
